definitions.definition: the normal order and way in which you regularly do things

examples.text: We are trying to get the baby into a routine for feeding and sleeping.
In school, I quickly fell into the routine.
Make exercise a part of your **daily routine**.
A pressing work project had disrupted his normal sleep routine.
There's never a bad time to begin a new exercise routine.
We clean and repair the machines as a matter of routine.
Don't cut back on your regular fitness routine.
Everyone has their own morning routine.
It took me a week to settle into a routine.
She fell into a routine of taking the baby to the park after lunch.
The children were confused by the change of routine.
Their schedules and routines are seldom monotonous.
Work out a routine for updating the list regularly.
Her aim was to establish some kind of order and routine in the place.

definitions.definition: a situation in which life is boring because things are always done in the same way

examples.text: He tries to escape the dull routine of his office life.

definitions.definition: a series of movements, jokes, etc. that are part of a performance

examples.text: We need some new material for our routine.

definitions.definition: a list of instructions that enable a computer to perform a particular task

wordOrigin: late 17th cent. (denoting a regular course or procedure): from French, from route ‘road’, from Old French rute ‘road’, from Latin rupta (via) ‘broken (way)’, feminine past participle of rumpere.
